data.sampled: $376.26 (Sell): -$3.74 (-$390/$15.55 - 1 + 1 = -$3.74), $376.26 (Buy): -$3.74 ($394/$13.18 - 1 + 1 = -$3.74). This assumes the calls have no intrinsic value at expiration (i.e., the stock price is equal to the exercise/strike price). The breakeven stock price would be the sum of the premium paid for each option plus the difference between the strike prices minus any dividends received during that time. In this case, there would be no dividend payment as it was not specified. Therefore, the total breakeven stock price would be the sum of the absolute values of the net premiums paid per share for both options. The resulting breakeven stock prices are $376.26 for selling the $390 call and $376.26 for buying the $394 call. These calculations assume that all options were bought on the same day, had identical terms such as expiration date and implied volatility, and that the risk-free rate was constant over the life of the options. It also assumes that no transaction costs, taxes, or slippage occurred when trading the options. Additionally, please note that the above calculation does not take into account potential changes in market conditions, which may affect the stock's future performance. Always consult a financial advisor before making any trades. This information is provided only for educational purposes and is intended solely for use by experienced traders who understand the risks associated with buying and writing options and trading futures contracts. data.sampled:
Max Loss: -$498.50 (if stock price goes below $205)
Max Gain: $637.50 (if stock price goes above $210)
For calculations please refer to standard Call Option pricing formula.
Please note that these answers assume a European style option and that there are no transaction costs involved. Also, the calculation assumes the current time as t=0 and r=0 since it was not provided. Furthermore, the answer provided does not take into account any dividends paid by the underlying company before expiration of options which would change the Black-Scholes model parameters (spot, strike, volatility, risk free rate, and time to expiration). This would impact both the maximum gain and maximum loss for each individual option, but will have the opposite effect on the difference between them (i.e., the net credit received when selling the lower striking OTM call minus buying the higher striking ITM call), meaning that the overall max gain/max loss remains the same. Lastly, keep in mind that this ignores bid-ask spreads and commissions that may occur based on market conditions and brokerage fees. Thus the real world results could differ slightly than calculated here. However, using realistic estimates based on historical data and/or recent market trends can get you much closer to actual numbers; thus providing more accurate predictions. Nonetheless, the figures presented should still provide a good representation of how changes in stock prices affect your potential gains and losses when taking positions such as those described. Additionally, given equal quantities of long & short calls, if the long call has a larger profit, the strategy breaks even whereas if the short call has a smaller loss, then the strategy makes money; otherwise, the strategy incurs a net loss which equals |net loss on short call| + |profit on long call|. The first number represents the lower bound of the range (the minimum stock price where you would start losing money), while the second number represents the upper bound of the range (the maximum stock price where you would break even). In this case, if the stock price is above $103.50 but below $106.78 ($104 + $2.00 - $1.50 = $106.78) then you would neither make nor lose any money on these trades. If the stock price falls outside of this range then you will either make or lose money depending on whether it is higher or lower than the appropriate boundary. Keep in mind that there may still be transaction costs associated with buying and selling options that can affect your actual profit/loss.

data.sampled: The breakeven stock prices for this strategy are $205.00 (for short call) and $216.67 (for long call). This can be calculated by subtracting the premium received for selling the first call ($5.00) and adding the premium paid for buying the second call ($1.50), then adding that amount to the strike price of each respective option. In this case, the difference between these two figures represents the range within which there may be profit potential for this spread trade. For example, if the underlying stock's market price at expiration falls below $205.00 but above $210.00, both calls would expire worthless, resulting in a net credit gained through the sale of the more expensive call and purchase of the less expensive call. Conversely, if the underlying stock rises above $216.67, both options will have intrinsic value greater than zero, resulting in a debit equal to the difference between the two premiums minus the difference between their respective exercise prices. However, if the stock price closes exactly on either of these breakeven points on the specified expiration date, neither option would result in any gain or loss due to time decay as they were both bought/sold for $0.00 premium.
